text: PAUL PETROVICH, called as a witness herein, having been first duly sworn on oath, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION

Good morning, Paul.  Again, my name is Joseph Blum.  I represent Mercedes Benz in a case that's been brought by Capitol Indemnity. I'm just going to ask you a series of questions this morning.  If at any time you don't understand my question, please tell me and I'll be happy to restate it. Also, we're doing this via video connection, so there is going to be some lag time at points where -- between when we speak. So I'm going to ask you to try to take your time and let me finish speaking before you respond.  Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And we do have to have you keep all your responses verbal, because the court reporter cannot take down nods of our heads or shrugs of our shoulders. Do you understand that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anything that would prevent from you testifying accurately this morning?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  By whom are you employed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Capitol Specialty Corporation, also known as Capitol Indemnity Corporation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you been employed there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Seventeen years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And could you just briefly tell us the history of your employment there at Capitol?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At Capitol?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was hired as a property examiner, specifically for background in arson, which I had done previously in Chicago.  And then there was some curtailing of business, so I went and handled some other lines of business for about three or four years, liability, auto, because of my background on that, too, but then came back to property.  So essentially, out of 17 years I was probably doing property for 13 years out of the 17.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And over the last five years, what have you been doing?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Property.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is that --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Commercial property.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry, say that again.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Commercial property.  We don't do any personal lines.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, okay. And are you typically on a day-to-day basis adjusting losses for business property?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And before you came to Capitol, can you tell me just briefly what your employment history had been?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Immediately before coming to Capitol I spent a year and a half working for L.J. Shaw & Company in Lombard, Illinois, as an independent adjustor handling, again, commercial -- primarily commercial property but some residential as well there. Prior to that I worked -- I had my own construction company for four years, from '97 to 2001, servicing the insurance industry doing insurance repairs. Prior to that, from '87 to '97 I was with American States Insurance primarily handling commercial property claims but some homeowner's or residential, but 90 percent of the business was commercial. Immediately before that, from '81 to '87 I was with the Illinois Fair Plan Association, which almost exclusively handled residential property claims. And then prior to that, from '76 to '81 I worked for Economy Fire & Casualty basically doing a hodgepodge of residential property, auto, and even some bodily injury claims, minor ones.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that was your first employment?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  In the insurance business.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Okay.  And tell me what your educational background is.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I have a B.S. degree in business management from Northern Illinois University.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you obtain that degree?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Let's see.  That would have been 1974.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And since you obtained your degree, have you obtained any other certificates or degrees or anything like that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not specific degrees.  I've taken classes and courses, but not essentially -- not like a CPCU or anything like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What, if anything, did you do to prepare for your deposition today other than speaking to Gus?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Looked up some of the information on the payments, because Gus had indicated you might be interested in knowing how those payments came to be.  And since it's been a significant period of time since I've worked on the file, I'm trying to refresh my memory here; it's not what it once was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the file that you're speaking about is your insured was a company called S-Bond; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this fire occurred in Lansdale, Pennsylvania. Have you ever personally visited the site?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the stack of documents that should be there with you there are I want to say the seventh document which is called the Plaintiff Capitol Indemnity Corporation's Responses to Defendant Mercedes Benz First Interrogatories. Can you see if you can locate that document for me?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: What was the name of that document again?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  It has the caption of the case on it, and it's entitled Plaintiff Capitol Indemnity Corporation's Responses to Defendant Mercedes Benz First Interrogatories.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: In front of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Have you ever seen this document before?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  I'm going to direct your attention, if we could, to the answer to Interrogatory No. 60, which appears -- the question is on page 14, and the answer is on page 15.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Question 60 did you say?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  That is correct.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And that question is asking for a detailed itemization of the elements of damage that Capitol is claiming. Do you see that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Um-hmm, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the answer that's provided here in the interrogatories is $248,843.17. Do you see that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that an accurate statement as to what you're claiming?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  The only caveat to that is that includes the insured's $1,000 deductible.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And can you tell me, are there -- there should be like groups or categories of damages that make up that 248,000.  What are the different groups?  Like property damage, business interruption?  Can you tell me what the categories are?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, the basic categories are business personal property and then business income and extra expense.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell me the business personal property, what is the amount of the claim that is being made by Capitol?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe it is 117,389.17.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And does that include the $1,000 deductible?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So really your number before the deductible is 116,389.17?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Can you tell me how Capitol went about determining that number?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, we hired an independent adjustor to meet with the insured.  The insured's business is fairly complicated, because I think they do some work for the government.  And I believe it has to do with satellites, but I'm not 100 percent sure on all of that.  But they've got a system where they were using what I would refer to as top-end electronic equipment for either calculating and/or effecting the actual work that they're doing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who is the independent adjustor that Capitol retained?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe that was James Farr or Jamie Farr.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you personally know Mr. Farr before this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How did you come to hire him?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I've worked with Johns Eastern Company previously, and he was in the locale where the loss occurred, so I hired Johns Eastern.  They assigned Mr. Farr.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is your understanding of the business of Johns Eastern Company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They're an independent adjusting company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And was Mr. Farr authorized to act as your agent to adjust the loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: For the adjustment purpose of the loss, yes, to talk to the insured.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Correct. And that number that you gave us, the $116,000 number, does that represent a replacement cost for the insured or actual cash value?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe that would be replacement cost.  A lot of the items that were involved were, in fact, cleaned, because the insured was desperate to relocate to another location.  So they were trying everything in their power to clean items that they could use, but due to the nature of being electronic equipment, some of them were not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm sorry, you lost me there a little bit. So in the 117,000 -- 116,000, does that include the effort to clean, or is that just the amount that was paid for replacement?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is cleaning and also what I would refer to as pack-out.  Because obviously if they're going to take items from location one, wherever they were located at, Lansdale, and then move it to another property, they were going to clean the property before they moved into the other location. So you're paying for the cleaning of the equipment and then loading it into a truck, taking it over to the new location, as well as some items that could not be cleaned, had to be replaced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you receive from Johns Eastern a breakdown of all of those costs?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And in what form did you receive that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Usually it's in a summary of either damages that were allowed for replacement or cleaning invoices from specific companies that were hired and for moving the equipment as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And before you came to your deposition today, did you review the file that you had on this matter?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Briefly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you see that summary of damages in your file?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: A specific one for each category?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, at any time.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  Yes, I saw inventories that were prepared by the insured that Mr. Farr reviewed and then analyzed and then sent a recommendation to our office saying I've looked at this and this is a recommendation for payment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you follow the recommendations of Mr. Farr?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: For the most part since he was on site.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, do we know were there some which were rejected?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I can't tell you off the top of my head for things that were done like three years ago.  I couldn't tell you off the top of my head.  I'm sure it might be something that was questioned.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And the copies of the invoices for the stuff that was cleaned and shipped, do you see those in your file?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: There were invoices in there, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you know of the items that were replaced, did you or anyone acting on your behalf determine what the actual cash value was of those items that were replaced?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Again, without looking at the documents, I couldn't tell you off the top of my head.  I believe a lot of them were replaced immediately because the insured, like I say, wanted to get back into business.  So if he needed a machine or a piece of equipment that we agreed was damaged, he would purchase it and then have it delivered to the new location where he was setting up his business.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And to the best of your knowledge, you have not seen any determination of the actual cash value of the equipment that was replaced?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I can't say that there was no determination on that, because I -- again, I'm not looking at each and every specific, you know, report and inventory.  There may have been.  I just can't say that I know what exactly that ACV or actual cash value figure is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than yourself, is there anyone at Capitol who would have known that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And other than in your file for this matter, is there anyplace else where that documentation would have existed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Probably Mr. Farr's file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was Mr. Farr authorized to act on your -- on Capitol's behalf to make a determination of the actual cash value of the replacement for the equipment?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you discuss your deposition with Mr. Farr before you came here today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you discuss your deposition with anyone else?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Mr. Sara --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than me.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: Other than your counsel.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Advised my immediate boss that I was going to be required to come for a deposition and mentioned it to Brad Temple who is the current supervisor of the file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, you had also mentioned that there was a claim for business income; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And is that separate from the extra expense, or were they together?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's together, because the coverage is called business income and extra expense.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know what is the total amount that was paid by Capitol on that coverage, business income and extra expense?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Let's see.  I was printing some things out before I left, but the computer was not cooperative in terms of printing information. It's $131,000.  I just can't give you the specifics on it here, because it's, like I said, in the computer.  Somebody more computer savvy than I need to look at that to print it out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that include additional rent, that number?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  That's part of the extra expense.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Give me one second. I'm sorry, did you say 131,454?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The 454 I didn't know off the top of my head. I knew the 131.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And are there any other damages that were paid other than the 117 and the 131 that we just talked about?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Just adjustment expenses, which is not included in any of this.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Then as far as I can tell, my number does not add up to -- somewhere we're missing something in terms of the 248 total that you gave us.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  What numbers are you adding?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just adding the 117 and the 131.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And then did you -- that comes to 248 to me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I guess what I'm missing is the deductible.  That's where I was off.  Okay. Great. And so there are no other additional damages that were paid?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  The business income and extra expense, can you tell me how that was determined?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I hired a forensic CPA firm called Insight Forensic Accountants.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did Insight Forensic Accountants provide you with a final report which listed everything that was paid?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't know about a final report.  They were giving me information leading up to it, because the primary extra expenses occurred in the first two or three months to pack out and move the business to the other location. If memory serves me correct, our insured wanted to move back to the building in Lansdale but was prohibited from doing so by the landlord, I'm not sure by what, if they rebuilt or didn't, but I believe he stayed in the building that he was at after the fire.  So there wasn't a pack-in back at the location for that reason.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were there a series of interim reports that you received to document the business income and extra expense?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I received some interim reports, but after a time the only thing that was being paid was the additional rents that were being incurred by the insured for having to rent this other location at a higher amount than they previously had been paid.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you could take a look at the documents that are in front of you there, I believe you'll find that there are a number of reports there from CapSpecialty.  If you could just pull any one of them out, that would be fine.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Reports to CapSpecialty?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: From CapSpecialty.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  Reports from CapSpecialty to whom?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Like to S-Bond Technologies.  I used the wrong term.  Correspondence.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  I've come across one dated December 28th to S-Bond from myself.  Is that what you're referring to?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah, that's a good example.  So every time -- my question is, every time that you sent a check or a payment to S-Bond Technologies, did you do so via correspondence like this?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Ordinarily I would try to do so on every payment to document my file on what I'm paying and why I'm paying it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And if we went through your file, would we find similar correspondence for each of the payments that were made to S-Bond by Capitol?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would believe so, yes, similarly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you in the end receive a final sworn statement and proof of loss from the insured for all of the property damage claims that they made?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I can say that we got the property -- the proof of loss for the business personal property. In the short time I was looking at it before coming here, I didn't notice that we had a proof of loss for the entire business income claim, but I haven't gone through the whole -- we have electronic files only, so there's no paper, and that consists of 1700 pages of things, so I'm looking through a computer screen to see if I can locate this. So I can't say that definitely we have one or that we don't have one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And if we asked you to look in your file for reports that came from Insight Forensic Accountants, where would you look in that file?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: In my file it would be under damages.  And they were producing reports --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And would those reports from Insight all be together?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They would be in the damage category in the computer file, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And did each of those reports -- were they like a multiple-page report where he would have a schedule -- the accountant had a schedule attached?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, but some of them became repetitious after the first six months, because the only thing that the insured was actually out-of-pocket was the difference in his rental income.  So we weren't reproducing that each and every time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Were you ever at any point involved in any inspections that had to do with the investigation of this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Me personally?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you ever have any meetings or discussions directly with the insured?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I spoke to the insured on multiple occasions, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were those conversations about the amount of the claim?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were there ever any discussions with him about the cause of the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, we discussed it early on in the claim, but he, frankly, didn't know a lot about it, because the actual fire started in the next-door location, so it was only hearsay and information that he got from third parties.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what, if anything, did he tell you about the cause of the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That it started in the uniform -- I think it was a uniform or a rental -- a laundry place. There was some discussion that it may have started in or near a vehicle that was housed in the building.  Other than that, that's as specific as we ever got.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And have you ever had any discussions with Mercedes Benz or any representative of Mercedes Benz about this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you attended any other meetings or any meetings with any of the other insurance companies involved in claims for this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than what we've talked about today, did you have any other involvement in the adjustment of this claim?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I did hire the cause and origin company initially after the fire loss to see if we could determine what the cause of the fire was. About as specific as it ever got was that it was in the building next door, they did believe it came from a vehicle, but they would require additional testing and, you know, inspections. And that, quite frankly, didn't take place within the time frame I was handling -- or supervising the file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what was the name of that company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: To be honest, I can't even tell you.  I don't recall the name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I take it from your testimony that at some point the handling of this file was transferred from your supervision to some other person; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did that happen?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: After determination of the claim payments, which would have been sometime in 2017. Because the fire happened in June of 2016, the insured has coverage for 12 consecutive months' worth of business income and extra expense, so that would have terminated in June of 2017.  So I would assume that this file was transferred in July or August of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't have any either.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's it.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Discussion off the record.)
Normal delivery for me.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Electronic, please.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: Right.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Proceedings concluded at 10:30 a.m.) STATE OF WISCONSIN   ) COUNTY OF MILWAUKEE  ) I, Sarah A. Hart, RPR, RMR, CRR and Notary Public in and for the State of Wisconsin, do hereby certify that the preceding deposition was recorded by me and reduced to writing under my personal direction. I further certify that I am not a relative or employee or attorney or counsel of any of the parties, or a relative or employee of such attorney or counsel, or financially interested directly or indirectly in this action. In witness whereof, I have hereunder set my hand and affixed my seal of office on this 3rd day of September, 2019. SARAH A. HART, RPR/RMR/CRR Notary Public
